actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-)
source: Al Jazeera; Tradewinds; USCENTCOM; Yemeni Army - Houthi
notes: Interception: On 10 December 2024, US destroyers USS Stockdale and USS O'Kan, with support of a French warplane, intercepted 4 drones and 1 cruise missile launched by Houthi forces in Yemen targeting the warships and three US-owned, operated and flagged commercial ships they were accompanying while transiting through the Gulf of Aden. There were no casualties or material damage. Houthi forces claimed to have targeted three US 'support' ships and an unspecified number of US destroyers after leaving port in Djibouti. Although the ships were unnamed, they were likely the Maersk Saratoga container ship (IMO: 9289207), the Stena Impeccable chemical/oil products tanker (IMO: 9693020) and the Liberty Grace bulk carrier (IMO: 9228148), which were targeted by the Houthis on November 30 and December 1 while transiting the Gulf of Aden and anchored at Djibouti afterwards. The attack started the day prior (coded separately).

The reason behind the abduction was a complaint by the businessman against the supervisor who had arrested him previously and looted his car. The businessman was at the Ministry of Interior to give his testimony regarding the incident when he was abducted and taken to an unknown destination.
Movement of forces: On 9 December 2024, Houthi forces began mobilizing reinforcements and deploying additional troops toward Marib Governorate (coded to governorate capital Marib City).

Movement of forces: On 9 December 2024, Houthi forces sent military reinforcements to Ibb Governorate (coded to governorate center Ibb city) (Al Mashannah) amid escalating public unrest demanding justice for the assassination of Sheikh Ash Shaar on 25 November in Sanaa.

source: Al Harf 28; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); Yemen Window
notes: On 9 December 2024, unidentified gunmen attacked and shot a delegation from the political office of the National Resistance in Marib governorate (coded to governorate capital Marib City) while en route to commemorate the anniversary of former President Ali Abdullah Saleh's death. The attack injured the head of the Ibb branch and 2 of his escorts. They were transferred to a hospital.

On 9 December 2024, tribal gunmen shot at telecommunications engineers while they were repairing a communications tower in Heed Al Masna'a area of Rada District (coded to district center Radaa) (Al Bayda). The attack was linked to demands for the release of tribal detainees held by Houthi authorities, resulted in 1 engineer falling to his death and injuring another.

On 9 December 2024, workers of 'Delsey' factory protested in Al Marawiah district on the main road between Al Hudaydah governorate and Sanaa (coded to district center Al Marawiah) against the Houthi forces closing the factory and barring employees from entering the premises. The protesters closed the road during their protest, likely by standing on it.

On 9 December 2024, hundreds of residents held a protest in Merkhah Al Ulya district (coded to district center Al Aqir) (Shabwah) denouncing the disregard of their concerns by the authorities and the decline in the level of public services.

source: Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); Twitter; Yemen Window
notes: On 8 December 2024, a suspected Houthi ballistic missile fell and exploded in an area near Al Mahruq village in Al Wadea district (coded to district center Al Wuday) (Abyan). There were no casualties. Sources suggested that the missile was likely a Falaq AShM or Qasim BM.

source: 26 September News - IRG; Aden al Ghad; Al Masdar; Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Yemen Window
notes: On 8 December 2024, a suspected Houthi landmine exploded on a farm in Ar Rimmah (Al Mukha, Taizz), injuring 1 farmer and damaging his tractor. There were no fatalities.

Other: On 8 December 2024, Houthi security forces prevented protesters from holding a scheduled protest in front of the governorate administrative building in Ibb City (Ibb). The protest's purpose was to demand the arrest of a Houthi militant accused of murder.

source: Al Masirah; Yemen News Agency (SABA) - Houthi
notes: On 8 December 2024, protesters held a Houthi-sponsored protest stand in the Al Kubah area in Al Jabin district (coded to district center Al Jabin) (Raymah) in solidarity with the Palestinian people and with Houthi actions against the 'Zionist enemy' in the context of the latest round of violence in Israel-Palestine.

On 8 December 2024, Houthi security forces opened fire on dozens of African immigrants (likely Ethiopian and Somali) protesters demonstrating in Houthi headquarters located in the Martyrs Mosque next to the Ministry of Defense headquarters in Sanaa - Al Urdi (Assafiyah, Amanat al Asimah) killing 3 people and injuring a number of others. According to the sources, dozens of African immigrants who were brought by the Houthi to Sanaa for recruitment purposes, carried out a sit-in the day inside one of the Houthi headquarters in protest against their continued detention and exploitation.

source: Al Masirah; Yemen News Agency (SABA) - Houthi

There were no damages to either US destroyers or the commercial ships. The Houthis claimed that they have targeted three 'US supply military ships' in the Gulf of Aden and the Arabian Sea and that they fired 16 ballistic and cruise missiles and drones, claiming they achieved 'direct and precise hits.' However, only the Stena Impeccable is confirmed to be contracted in initiatives to support the US defense sector. US forces intercepted another Houthi attack targeting the ships the previous day (coded separately). The Houthis claimed to have attacked the Maersk Saratoga on 23 March 2024, but the ship's owning company and non-Houthi sources denied the attack took place.

actor1: Police Forces of Yemen (2017-) Houthi - Prison Guards
notes: Around 29 November 2024 (as reported), 1 female prisoner who's is an activist journalist was tortured and poisoned in the central prison in Sanaa - Al Jiraf East (Shuaub, Amanat al Asimah). The prisoner was transferred to the prison hospital and then taken to the ICU in a hospital outside the prison. The source claimed the prisoner was poisoned through her food which worsened her medial status in addition to the torture she had been exposed to during her detention. The activist was abducted on 11 September (coded on a separate event).
tags: women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders

notes: On 29 November 2024, for the forth consecutive day, tribesmen from Ash Shaar tribe organized a sit-in protest in Sanaa - As Sabain Square (As Sabain, Amanat al Asimah) denouncing the killing of Ash Shaar tribal sheikh on 25th of November and demanding the accountability of the perpetrators. Houthi military forces removed the tents of the protesters and dispersed the sit-in protest. There were no casualties.

notes: On 25 November 2024, suspected Houthi militants assassinated a Ash Shaar tribal sheikh from Ibb in Dar Salam (Sanhan, Sanaa), shooting him while he was driving by a security checkpoint. source: 2 December News; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Mareb Press
notes: On 25 November 2024, a Houthi militant assaulted the Director of the Public Works Fund in Al Qaidah (Dhi As Sufal District, Ibb), following his refusal to pay extortion demands. source: 2 December News; Al Harf 28; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); Yemen Window
notes: On 24 November 2024, a suspected Houthi landmine exploded east of Al Hudaydah - 7 July neighborhood (Al Hali, Al Hudaydah), killing 1 (44-year-old) displaced civilian who worked in scrap metal collection.

source: 2 December News; Al Harf 28; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); Yemen Window
notes: On 24 November 2024, a suspected Houthi landmine exploded in Al Hudaydah city, injuring two civilians. Both men lost their sight due to shrapnel injuries caused by the camouflaged tube-shaped mine.

On 24 November 2024, an unidentified armed group attacked a house in the Aqqan area (Al Musaymir, Lahij), killing 1 resident and another injured. The attack was linked to a land dispute. Authorities have arrested the six perpetrators, and the incident is under investigation.

On 24 November 2024, Houthi militants assaulted a citizen (unspecified form of assault) in the Hazm Al Udayn district center (Ibb). The victim was attacked by five militants as he returned from collecting a money transfer.

source: Al Harf 28; Mareb Press; Yemen Window
notes: Property destruction: On 24 November 2024, Houthi forces raided the village of Uzlat Al Hawj al Qibli (Ibb), firing at homes and farms and burning three motorcycles. There reason for the raid is unclear.

notes: On 24 November 2024, an unidentified armed group robbed, tortured, and burned the son of a tribal sheikh in his home Sanaa - Madhbah (Maain). The reason for the attack remains unknown. 1 Fatality.

notes: On 20 November 2024, dozens of teachers held a protest in front of the governorate council in Ataq City (Ataq, Shabwah) to demand their financial rights. Joint forces composed of STC Shabwani Defense Forces and General Security divisions (coded as IRG generic police) stormed the protest, tore their banners, and forced the protesters to disperse. There were no casualties.

actor1: Police Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council
notes: On 20 November 2024, police forces arrested 318 illegal immigrants of Ethiopian and Somali nationality in Bir Ali (Rudum, Shabwah). The source claimed that the migrants arrived on a smuggling boat to the Bir Ali area.

actor1: AQAP: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
actor2: Military Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council - STC Support and Reinforcement Brigades
source: Aden al Ghad; An Nusra Media; Khabar News Agency (Yemen)
notes: On 20 November 2024, AQAP militants ambushed an ambulance carrying an injured soldier from the STC 3rd Support and Reinforcement Brigades in Umm Surrah (Mudiyah, Abyan), resulting in the killing of 2 and the injury of 1 STC soldier. The AQAP militants had targeted the injured STC soldier with Steyr sniper rifles in the Drone Control Center in Al Kasarah in Wadi Awmran region in an initial attack (coded as a separate event).

On 19 November 2024, the 9th Giants Brigade (coded under WCJF) clashed with Houthi forces and 'thwarted their attack' in Hays front (Hays, Al Hudaydah) using medium and heavy weapons causing 'heavy human losses' among Houthi forces. Unclear fatalities coded as 10.

source: 2 December News; Aden al Ghad; Al Harf 28; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); Yemen Window
notes: On 19 November 2024, clashes erupted between Houthi forces and tribesmen from Bani Nawf tribe in a checkpoint east of Al Hazm district (coded to district center Al Hazm) (Al Jawf). The reason behind the clashes was due to Houthi forces killing a tribesman from Bani Nawf at the same checkpoint (coded as a separate event).

source: Aden al Ghad; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG
notes: On 19 November 2024, Houthi forces attacked a group of civilians as they were leaving the court in Amanat al Asimah (coded to governorate capital Sanaa) in an apparent assassination attempt. The Houthi gunmen shot at a civilian and his relative, injuring 1 of the relatives. The source claimed that the targets were the father and a relative of a girl who was raped by a Houthi member (coded separately). The reason behind the incident was to force the father to pardon the perpetrator.

assoc_actor_2: Government of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council; Women (Yemen)
source: Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Khabar News Agency (Yemen)
notes: On 19 November 2024, unidentified armed men attacked the director of the governmental human rights office in Lahj Governorate as she was leaving her house with her son in Al Hawtah district (coded to district center Al Hawtah) (Lahj). The source claimed that as she was leaving her house gunmen started to assault her and when she responded to them they beat her and her son and threatened them with their weapons.

actor1: AQAP: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
actor2: Military Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council - STC Shabwani Defense Forces
notes: On 19 November 2024, AQAP militants claimed to have fired sniper shots at 'UAE mercenaries' (coded as STC Shabwani Defense Forces) in Al Qanaah site in Al Musayniah (As Said, Shabwah). Casualties unknown.

Interception: On 19 November 2024, ground defenses of the Giants Brigades intercepted a suspected Houthi drone (likely reconnaissance) flying over Ash Shuhada Camp area (Ataq, Shabwah). This comes after drones were flying over Ataq since the evening of November 17.

source: 2 December News; Aden al Ghad; Al Harf 28; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); Yemen Window
notes: On 19 November 2024, Houthi forces killed 1 tribesman from Bani Nawf tribe in a checkpoint east of Al Hazm district (coded to district center Al Hazm) (Al Jawf). The reason behind the attack was not reported. The killing led to clashes between Bani Nawf armed tribesmen and Houthi forces later on the same day (coded separately).

source: Aden al Ghad; Al Masdar; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Al Masirah; Ansar Allah; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); The Washington Institute; Tradewinds; UKMTO; Yemen News Agency (SABA) - Houthi; Yemeni Army - Houthi
notes: On 18 November 2024, at around 12:58 pm Sanaa time, Houthi forces fired at least 1 ballistic missile targeting the Anadolu S bulk carrier (IMO: 9667758) in the Gulf of Aden around 60 nm southeast of Aden, claiming affiliation with companies in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missile impacted the water around the ship. The ship continued to its next port of call. According to JMIC, the ship had an 'indirect association' to Israel. The vessel's owner was linked to at least one ship seen in Israel in early October, but it was unclear if it had more direct ties to Israel. The ship was targeted once before the previous day (coded as a separate event).

actor1: AQAP: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
actor2: Military Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council - STC
notes: On 18 November 2024, AQAP militants carried out a sniper operation targeting 'UAE mercenaries' (coded as STC generic forces) in Imbaqirah (Mudiyah, Abyan) killing 1 STC soldier.

actor1: Police Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council - STC Aden Security
actor2: Police Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council - STC Aden Security
notes: On 18 November 2024, STC security forces (coded as STC Aden Security) arrested the director of the Al Imad Police station at Aden - Al Imad (Dar Sad), after surrounding and besieging the department for three hours. The director was taken to an unknown location.

On 18 November 2024, tribesmen protested the appointment of an individual accused of involvement in the Al Hafra neighborhood bombings, in reference to incident in which Houthi forces destroyed houses with explosives for alleged security reasons, to a senior security position in Rada district (coded to district center Radaa) (Al Bayda). The tribes demanded his return to detention and threatened to seek justice themselves if the Houthi government fails to act.

source: 2 December News; 26 September News; Al Harf 28; Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Khabar News Agency (Yemen)
notes: On 18 November 2024, a projectile leftover from previous unidentified military activity exploded in At Taif (Ad Durayhimi, Al Hudaydah) severely injuring 1 (13-year-old) boy. Sources differed as to the origin of the device (Houthi or anti-Houthi).

source: 2 December News; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG
notes: On 18 November 2024, members of Houthi Central Security forces protested near the Sanaa - Saudi German Hospital (Bani Al Harith, Amanat al Asimah) against the 'embezzlement' of their wages by Houthi authorities. The protesting Houthi Central Security forces arrived aboard 20 military vehicles from their stations in Al Jubah district in Marib to accuse the Houthi leadership of stealing their salaries.

source: Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Yemen Window
notes: On 18 November 2024, an unidentified tribal gunman from Sadah governorate opened fire using a Kalashnikov at Houthi supervisor west of Sanaa city (coded to Sanaa - Qaryat Asr) (Maain, Amanat al Asimah). The Houthi official was critically injured and transferred to a hospital. The motive behind the attack is unknown, but one source speculated that it likely occurred due disagreements with other Houthi officials from Sadah Governorate over levies and land grabs in the Asr area west of Sanaa city.

Property destruction: On 18 November 2024, 10 Houthi officers demolished a civilian's house in Hammam Ali (Al Manar, Dhamar) using agricultural machinery and displaced the family. The Houthis claimed the house was built on disputed land between Hammam Ali and another village.

source: 26 September News; Al Sahil Al Gharbi
notes: On 18 November 2024, a suspected Houthi landmine exploded in an area north of Hajjah governorate (coded to district center Hajar) (Haradh), severely injuring 1 man and amputating his leg.

source: 2 December News; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG
notes: Movement of forces: On 18 November 2024, Houthi Central Security Forces evacuated their positions in Al Jubah District (coded to district center Judaydah) (Marib) and returned to Sanaa in a convoy of 20 vehicles. The forces accused the Houthi leadership of withholding their salaries. Upon arrival, they gathered near the Saudi Hospital in northern Sanaa to protest against the alleged embezzlement of their wages (coded as a separate event).

actor1: Military Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council - Political Security Organization
source: Al Masirah; Yemen News Agency (SABA) - Houthi
notes: Around 18 November 2024 (as reported), IRG Political Security Organization forces tortured and killed 1 prisoner in a prison in Marib governorate (coded to governorate center Marib City). According to Houthi media sources, the killed detainee was a Murad tribesman, who was captured incommunicado for four years in the custody of the Political Security Organization. His family discovered his body in a hospital morgue showing signs of torture after being informed of his death by another detainee.

source: 2 December News; 26 September News; Al Harf 28; Al Masirah; Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Ansar Allah; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); Yemen News Agency (SABA) - Houthi; Yemen Window
notes: On 18 November 2024, a suspected Houthi landmine exploded in a civilians farm in Al Mubdia village in Iyal Ghufayr (Nihm, Sanaa) severely injuring 1 (60-year-old) man. He was transferred to Sanaa hospital for treatment.

On 18 November 2024, for the third consecutive day, tribal gunmen from Al Jaadani tribes blocked (likely by establishing a flying checkpoint) the international road in Abyan governorate (coded to Lahmar area based on previous activity) (Mudiyah) connecting Aden and with eastern governorates and to stop the passing of fuel tankers in protest and to pressure IRG authorities into revealing the fate of Ali Ashal Al Jaadani, a colonel from Abyan governorate that was abducted at the hands of suspected STC Security Belt forces on 12 June. On 23 November, Al Jaadani tribe lifted the roadblocks in response to mediation led by the sheikhs of the Maraqisha tribes.

source: The Washington Institute; Tradewinds; UKMTO; Yemeni Army - Houthi
notes: On 17 November 2024, at around 7:13 pm Sanaa time, suspected Houthi forces fired at least 1 ballistic missile targeting the Anadolu S bulk carrier (IMO: 9667758) in the Strait of Bab el Mandeb around 25 nm west of Al Mukha, claiming affiliation with companies in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missile impacted the water 500m from the ship. According to JMIC, the ship had an 'indirect association' with Israel. The vessel's owner was linked to at least one ship seen in Israel in early October, but it was unclear if it had more direct ties to Israel. The ship continued to its next port of call. The ship was targeted again the following day (coded as a separate event).

source: Al Harf 28; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG
notes: On 17 November 2024, tribal clashes erupted between Al Dawla and Al Yaslam tribes in the general market of Ahwar District (coded to district center Ahwar) (Abyan). The clashes resulted in the death of 1 civilian and the injury of another. The reason for the clashes was a tribal vendetta.

On 17 November 2024, for the second consecutive day, tribal gunmen from Al Jaadani tribes blocked (likely by establishing a flying checkpoint) the international road in Abyan governorate (coded to Lahmar area based on previous activity) (Mudiyah) connecting Aden and with eastern governorates and to stop the passing of fuel tankers in protest and to pressure IRG authorities into revealing the fate of Ali Ashal Al Jaadani, a colonel from Abyan governorate that was abducted at the hands of suspected STC Security Belt forces on 12 June.

actor2: Military Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council
source: Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Al Sahil Al Gharbi
notes: On 17 November 2024, IRG forces and the 9th Giants Brigade clashed with Houthi forces and 'thwarted their infiltration attempt' on the Raghwan front (coded to district center Asdas) (Marib). Houthi forces used bomb-laden drones during the attack, killing 1 IRG soldier and injuring another.

Other: On 17 November 2024, Houthi authorities in Hamdan District (coded to district center Al Khaniq) (Sanaa) issued directives targeting wedding hall owners and couples. These directives restricted wedding celebrations, including limiting events to 8 PM, banning open windows, loudspeakers, and photographers, prohibiting grooms from entering halls to escort brides, and forbidding firing in the air during weddings. Violations are punishable by fines of up to 500,000 Yemeni riyals.

On 16 November 2024, tribal gunmen from Al Jaadani tribes blocked (likely by establishing a flying checkpoint) the international road in Abyan governorate (coded to Lahmar area based on previous activity) (Mudiyah) connecting Aden and with eastern governorates and to stop the passing of fuel tankers in protest and to pressure IRG authorities into revealing the fate of Ali Ashal Al Jaadani, a colonel from Abyan governorate that was abducted at the hands of suspected STC Security Belt forces on 12 June.

Property destruction: On 16 November 2024, unknown gunmen opened fire at the home of a tribal leader in an unspecified location in Ad Dali governorate (coded to governorate capital Ad Dali). It's unclear the house's inhabitants were present at the time of shooting. There were no fatalities.
On 16 November 2024, 2 gunmen dressed in security uniforms on a motorcycle threw a hand grenade at the home of a tribal leader in Lakmat ad Duki (Ad Dhalee, Ad Dali). There were no fatalities.

Security measures: Around 16 November 2024 (as reported), Houthi forces built extensive military fortifications at Al Hudaydah - Port (Al Hali, Al Hudaydah). The sources suggested that these measures were in anticipation of potential offensives in the area.

The sources suggested that these measures were in anticipation of potential offensives in the area.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-)
source: Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Ansar Allah; USCENTCOM; Yemen Window
notes: On 10 November 2024, US forces conducted airstrikes targeting Houthi military camps and weapons storage facilities in Sanaa - Al Hafaa (As Sabain, Amanat al Asimah). Casualties unknown. This was the second attack on the same site after a previous airstrike targeted it on 9 November 2024 (coded as a separate event). CENTCOM claimed the targeting of multiple Houthi weapons storage facilities on 9-10 November without providing locations, while Houthi sources reported raids on several locations in Amanat al Asimah, Sanaa, and Amran governorates.

source: 2 December News; Al Masdar; Khabar News Agency (Yemen)

Displacement: Around 8 November 2024 (as reported), Houthi forces evacuated hundreds of families in Ad Durayhimi district (coded to district center Ad Durayhimi) (Al Hudaydah). Non-violent activity: On 8 November 2024, Hadramawt Tribal Alliance created a new checkpoint on the international road in Rujaimah area in Brom Mayfa (Burum, Hadramawt).

On 7 November 2024, Houthi forces abducted a number of farmers in Saadah governorate (coded to governorate capital Sadah) (Sadah) after refusing to give up their lands to the Houthi forces as they rely on the lands' agricultural crops.

On 7 November 2024, Al al Bahri tribe clashed with Al Dahmar tribe in the market in Bayhan al Ulya (Bayhan, Shabwah) resulting in the killing of 2 tribesmen and the injury of 2 others. The reason behind the clash was not reported.

assoc_actor_1: Al Islah Party; Nasserist Unionist People's Organization; Yemeni Socialist Party; Justice and Building Party; Southern National Salvation Council; NSC: National Southern Coalition; National Resistance (Guards of the Republic); Al Rashad Union; National Arab Socialist Baath Party - Yemen Region; Southern Movement; Hadramawt National Council; Peace and Development Party; The National Council of Shabwah; Union of Popular Forces; Liberation Front Party; Yemeni Republican Federal Party; Yemen Renaissance Movement; People's Democratic Party; Yemeni Unionist Congregation
source: Al Harf 28; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Yemen Window
notes: Other: On 5 November 2024, the National Bloc of Political Parties and Components was launched in Coral Hotel at Aden - Ash Shabat (Khur Maksar) comprising 21 political entities. These include the General People's Congress, Al Islah Party, Yemeni Socialist Party, Nasserite Popular Unionist Organization, Political Bureau of the National Resistance, Southern Movement, Yemeni Rashad Union, Justice and Building Party, NSC: National Southern Coalition, Ennahda Movement for Peaceful Change, National Solidarity Party, Southern Revolutionary Movement, Yemeni Unity Gathering, Union of Popular Forces, Peace and Development Party, Arab Socialist Baath Party, Hadhramaut National Council, People's Democratic Party (Hashd), Shabwa National Council, Republican Party, and the Liberation Front Party. Dr. Ahmed Obaid bin Dagher was appointed as the bloc's head, which aims to restore the state, unify national forces, resolve the southern issue, support the Presidential Leadership Council, and emphasize economic stabilization and citizens' welfare amidst the ongoing crisis. Notably, the STC did not participate or joined the new formed National Bloc.

Movement of forces: On 5 November 2024, Houthi forces mobilized hundreds of fighters toward Al Hudaydah (coded to governorate center) southern coastal areas, preparing for possible clashes with Yemeni government forces. Additionally, Houthi leadership ordered the transfer of all central prison inmates in Al Hudaydah to Sanaa and directed merchants to urgently clear goods from the port, suggesting anticipation of potential conflict escalation.

On 5 November 2024, Houthi forces clashed with the 1st Zaraniq and 1st Tihama brigade off the Coast of Al Haymah (At Tuhayat, Al Hudaydah) using different kinds of weapons. The source claimed that the clashes resulted in major losses on the Houthi side. Unclear fatalities coded as 3.

source: Al Harf 28; Mareb Press; Yemen Window
notes: Other: On 5 November 2024, Houthi forces launched a campaign targeting internet shop owners across Sanaa - Al Wahdah and Maain districts (coded to Sanaa) to pressure them into paying fines, promoting Houthi ideologies, and contributing to military mobilization efforts. Houthi forces, affiliated with the Mobilization and Recruitment Department and the communications office, shut down several shops, accusing them of violating 'faith identity' by hosting content on science, sports, and entertainment. To reopen, shop owners were required to pay fines and commit to broadcasting materials that promote Houthi leadership ideologies.

actor1: Police Forces of Yemen (2017-) Houthi - Security and Intelligence Service
notes: On 5 November 2024, Houthi security forces arrested and detained 12 houthi members from Sanaa - Sanaa International Airport (Bani Al Harith, Amanat al Asimah) and transferred them to Security and Intelligence Service detention centers on charges of espionage for the Israeli Mossad. The detainees, 2nd and 3rd-tier leaders in Houthi ranks, had previously participated in conflicts in Sadah and recently returned from separate trips to Iraq and Iran via Jordan. Houthi sources claim the individuals visited Shiite sites and allegedly coordinated with sectarian authorities in Iraq.

source: Aden al Ghad; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG
notes: On 5 November 2024, Houthi forces fired mortar shells on Al Mansura village in Al Kadahah (Al Maafer, Taizz) injuring 1 woman inside her house.

Tribal leaders burned their traditional garments in anger, demanding the execution of the perpetrator and rejecting the court's ruling as insufficient. They called for the application of Islamic law and vowed not to accept any compromise in the case.

On 22 October 2024, members of the Preventive Security forces loyal to Ali Hussein Al Houthi ambushed the car of the Houthi Minister of Interior, Abdul Karim Al Houthi, in Al Azraqayn Checkpoint (Hamdan, Sanaa) in an assassination attempt. Regular security forces intervened, securing the minister and arresting the members of Preventive Security involved. There were no casualties.

The attack was not confirmed by other sources.

The abduction of the man happened on the same day (coded as a separate event).

notes: On 21 October 2024, Houthi forces fired 5 mortar shells at a civilian home in Hajar (coded to Naqil Hajar) (Qaatabah, Ad Dali), causing material damage. There were no casualties.

He was taken to an unknown location. He was previously detained and was released 3 months ago before the incident. Residents of the Az Zahari district held a protest against the abduction of the same day (coded as a separate event).

On 21 October 2024, in the afternoon, armed clashes broke out in Aden - Al Arish neighborhood (Khur Maksar, Aden) as an unidentified group surrounded a person inside a house, leading to heavy gunfire and explosions. The identity of those involved was not reported. Security forces intervened to contain the clashes. Casualties unknown.

Around 20 October 2024 (from 19 - 20 October), Houthi forces arrested around 40 farmers in Al Karb and Al Khawalid villages (Saqayn, Sadah). Sources claimed that the arrests followed the farmers' refusal to pay money demanded by Houthi authorities for the construction of a water dam.

source: 2 December News; Akhbar Taiz; Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Twitter
notes: On 20 October 2024, clashes resumed between Al Ulqimah tribal militants and National Resistance Forces (coded under WCJF) in Al Dharifa (Al Waziiyah, Taizz), killing 1 tribal militant (NRF according to one source) and injuring several others. The clashes first started on 30 September following the dismissal of a former NRF commander from the tribe due to internal disagreements, resulting in clashes between tribal militants loyal to him and the NRF (coded separately). On 5 October, the governor of Taizz mediated an agreement between the clashing sides to cease clashes and withdraw armed groups and military forces from the area. The clashes renewed on 20 October after the 2nd Giants Brigade, which was supervising the ceasefire, withdrew from the area. The tribal militants attacked a station belonging to the NRF forces.

Around 20 October 2024 (from 19 - 20 October), Houthi forces arrested around 40 farmers in Al Karb and Al Khawalid villages (Saqayn, Sadah). Sources claimed that the arrests followed the farmers' refusal to pay money demanded by Houthi authorities for the construction of a water dam.

notes: On 20 October 2024, Houthi gunmen shot and killed a young man in a street in Sanaa city (Amanat al Asimah). The reason behind the attack was not reported.

The source speculated that this was part of Houthi preparations for potential ground clashes with American and British forces.

source: Al Masdar; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; An Nusra Media; Khabar News Agency (Yemen)
notes: On 14 October 2024, AQAP militants fired an RPG rocket at a Shabwa Defense military vehicle in the Al Musayniah area (As Said, Shabwah). Some sources reported that AQAP targeted the vehicle with an IED instead. The explosion resulted in the death of the Chief of Staff of the 1st Shabwa Defense Brigade and left several others injured. AQAP media claimed responsibility for the attack and stated that it was carried out six months after a failed double assassination attempt on the Chief of Staff, during which one device caused only injury (coded separately). 1 fatality.

Strikes: On 14 October 2024, currency exchange companies in Aden governorate (coded to governate center) went on strike, suspending all buying and selling of foreign currencies due to the rapid collapse of the local currency. This action follows the decline of the Yemeni rial, with the exchange rate for US dollar exceeding 2,000 rials and the Saudi riyal reaching 520 rials.

On 14 October 2024, protesters held a large STC-sponsored protest march in Al Mahfad District (coded to district center, Al Mahfid) (Abyan) to commemorate the 61st anniversary of the 14 October Revolution and expressed solidarity with the Palestinian and Lebanese people

On 14 October 2024, protesters marched in Aden - Kraytar (Craiter, Aden) in support of the people of Gaza and against the Israeli 'aggression on the region' following the latest round of violence between Hamas and Israel in the Gaza Strip.

This directive included restricting wedding and event time to conclude at 9 p.m., prohibiting loudspeakers and photography, and banning the groom from entering the event hall.

On 14 October 2024, protesters held a STC-sponsored rally in Sayun city (Sayun, Hadramawt), under the banner of the 'Million Man Southern Identity' event, in conjunction with the 61st anniversary of the 14 October Revolution.

source: AP; Tradewinds; UK Royal Navy; UKMTO; Yemeni Army - Houthi
notes: On 10 October 2024, at around 3:10 am Sanaa time, Houthi forces fired 1 projectile (likely a drone according to Maritime intelligence firm Diaplous) targeting the Olympic Spirit chemical/oil products tanker (IMO: 9327097) in the South Red Sea around 70 nm southwest of Al Hudaydah, claiming US affiliation of the ship. The projectile hit the ship's bridge, causing minor damage, but no casualties. Houthi forces claimed to have used 11 ballistic missiles and 2 drones in their attack against the Olympic Spirit. The ship was targeted twice more on that day (coded as separate events). The US affiliation of the ship was not verified. According to TradeWinds, the ship was managed by the Greece-based Dynamic Shipmanagement at the time of the attack, although it used to be managed by the US-based Oaktree Capital Management and is still registered under the latter in at least one shipping database.

source: AP; Tradewinds; UK Royal Navy; UKMTO; Yemeni Army - Houthi
notes: On 10 October 2024, at around 6:30 am Sanaa time, Houthi forces fired 2 ballistic missiles targeting the Olympic Spirit chemical/oil products tanker (IMO: 9327097) in the South Red Sea around 70 nm southwest of Al Hudaydah, claiming US affiliation of the ship. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missiles impacted the water in close proximity to the ship. Houthi forces claimed to have used 11 ballistic missiles and 2 drones in their attack. The ship was targeted twice more on that day (coded as separate events). The US affiliation of the ship was not verified. According to TradeWinds, the ship was managed by the Greece-based Dynamic Shipmanagement at the time of the attack, although it used to be managed by the US-based Oaktree Capital Management and is still registered under the latter in at least one shipping database.

source: AP; Tradewinds; UK Royal Navy; UKMTO; Yemeni Army - Houthi

The projectile failed to reach the ship and impacted the waters in close proximity to the ship. Houthi forces claimed to have used 11 ballistic missiles and 2 drones in their attack. The ship was targeted twice more on that day (coded as separate events). The US affiliation of the ship was not verified. According to TradeWinds, the ship was managed by the Greece-based Dynamic Shipmanagement at the time of the attack, although it used to be managed by the US-based Oaktree Capital Management and is still registered under the latter in at least one shipping database.

On 10 October 2024, at an unspecified time, Houthi forces claimed a cruise missile attack targeting the St. John container ship (IMO: 9634646) in the Northwestern Indian Ocean, claiming affiliation with companies in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missile likely impacted the water before reaching the intended target. The attack was not confirmed by other sources. Houthi forces targeted the ship possibly because of its affiliation with Greece-based company Eastern Mediterranean Maritime, which had other ships affiliated to it dock at Israeli ports in early May. The St. John was located off the coast of Somalia, en route to the UAE.

source: 2 December News; Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Dera Al Ganoob; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); Yemen Window

On 7 October 2024, at an unspecified time, Houthi forces claimed to have launched an unspecified number of drones, including ones from the 'Sammad-4' and 'Yaffa' types, targeting sites in Eilat and Haifa in Israel (coded to North Red Sea). There were no fatalities or injuries as the drones likely impacted the water before reaching the intended targets. The attack was not confirmed by other sources.

On 7 October 2024, Houthi forces claimed to have lunched 2 missiles, including 1 'Palestine-2' and 1 'Zulfiqar' missile, targeting 2 military sites in the Tel Aviv area in Israel (coded to North Red Sea). One missile was intercepted by the IDF (coded separately to Israel), while the other likely impacted the water before reaching the intended target in the North Red Sea. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missile likely impacted the water before reaching the intended target. The attack was not confirmed by other sources.

notes: On 1 October 2024, at an unspecified time, Houthi forces claimed a cruise missile attack targeting the Marathopolis container ship (IMO: 9477804) in the Indian Ocean (coded to Northwestern Indian Ocean), claiming affiliation with companies in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missile likely impacted the water before reaching the intended target. The attack was not confirmed by other sources, and the ship was laden off Oman the following day before heading east to the next port of call in India. The Houthis claimed to target the ship again on the same day (coded separately). The Houthis have claimed a previous attack in the Marathopolis around 9 July that was also not confirmed by other sources (coded separately).

source: Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Al Masirah; Ansar Allah; Tradewinds; UKMTO; Yemen News Agency (SABA) - Houthi; Yemeni Army - Houthi
notes: On 1 October 2024, at around between 4:50 and 5:55 am Sanaa time, Houthi forces fired 4 missiles targeting the Cordelia Moon crude oil tanker (IMO: 9297888) in the South Red Sea around 64 nm northwest of Al Hudaydah, claiming affiliation with companies in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. The missiles failed to hit the ship and splashed in the water close to it, with the last missile hitting around 100 m from the ship. There were no casualties or damages. The Houthis claimed to have used 8 ballistic and cruise missiles, drones and drone boats in their attack. The ship was targeted again later on that day (coded as a separate event).

source: Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Al Masirah; Ansar Allah; Tradewinds; UKMTO; Yemen News Agency (SABA) - Houthi; Yemeni Army - Houthi
notes: On 1 October 2024, at around 8:00 am Sanaa time, Houthi forces fired 1 drone boat targeting the Cordelia Moon crude oil tanker (IMO: 9297888) in the South Red Sea around 64 nm northwest of Al Hudaydah, claiming affiliation with companies in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. The ship's security forces attempted to intercept the drone boat, but they were unsuccessful and it hit the ship, damaging it by puncturing a ballast tank. There were no casualties, and the ship processed to its next port of call. The Houthis claimed to have used 8 ballistic and cruise missiles, drones and drone boats in their attack. The ship was targeted earlier on that day (coded as a separate event).

On 1 October 2024, at around 7:15 am Sanaa time, suspected Houthi forces fired 1 missile targeting the Minoan Courage bulk carrier (IMO: 9288526) in the South Red Sea around 97 nm northwest of Al Hudaydah. The missile hit the ship, damaging its engine, and causing a fire, but causing no casualties among crew. The ship was stationary at the time of the attack. According to JMIC, the attack was likely unintentional, as the Houthis were targeting the Cordelia Moon crude oil tanker nearby (coded as a separate event). The Houthis did not claim the attack.

notes: Interception: On 16 September 2024, Houthi forces shot down a suspected US MQ-9 drone (unclear if armed) in the airspace of Dhamar Governorate (coded to governorate center Dhamar City). According to the Houthi military spokesperson, the drone was conducting 'espionage and hostile missions', claiming Houthi forces downed a total of nine MQ-9 drones since October 7. US forces announced that one of their drones crashed on the same day without specifying how it was downed, but that it was recovered by US forces.

On 16 September 2024, students and teachers at Abdelbari Qasim Girls High School in Khur Maksar district held a protest at the school (Coded to nearest location, Aden - Ras al Jarth) (Aden) to highlight the difficulties in conducting educational activities due to extreme heat and the lack of a solar energy system in the school building.

On 16 September 2024, for the second consecutive day, tribal protesters blocked the Aden - Shabwah road via unspecified means (coded to Lahmar area based on previous activity) (Mudiyah, Abyan) paralyzing transportation to demand the disclosure of the fate of Ali Ashal Al Jaadani, a colonel from Abyan governorate that was abducted at the hands of suspected STC Security Belt forces on 12 June. Hundreds of trucks and fuel tankers, heading to Ahwar and Al-Hamr, were stranded, leading to a fuel supply crisis in those areas. While the tribes allowed limited passage for trucks carrying commercial gasoline, they banned oil tankers from entering Aden Governorate.

Around 16 September 2024, a Houthi member of the military police shot and killed a Houthi government employee at a military checkpoint in Bayt al Lahida checkpoint in the Sawan area (Bani Hushaysh, Sanaa) while he was attending the celebration of the Prophet's birthday or Mawlid. The victim worked in the tax sector and was from Al Miftah District in Hajjah Governorate, and he was forced by the Houthis to attend a Mawlid celebration under threat of losing his job. He was shot by a Houthi leader from Dhamar Governorate. According to source, the killer was detained in a Sanaa provincial prison.

On 15 September 2024, Houthi forces launched 5 ballistic missiles toward Khamir district, with one striking a qat farm in Al Fusayrah village (Khamir, Amran), causing significant damage to the farm but no casualties. According to the source, four out of five missiles launched that night fell on the villages of Al Ayanah and Al Fusayrah.

On 6 September 2024, Giants Brigades forces abducted 1 civilian, who was the son of a tribal sheikh, from the Am Surayh junction (Al Madaribah Wa Al Arah, Lahij) and too him to unknown destination. The victim's father had been detained by the Giants Brigades and kept in an STC prison in Aden since May 2024. The abduction came one day after the victim started wide-scale efforts to release his father, including calling, via Facebook, on tribal leaders to act within 48 hours to pressure STC leaders into transferring his father's case to official government authorities.

On 3 September 2024, residents from Shahir in Ghayl Bawazir district continued their protest near Riyan International Airport (Al Mukalla City, Hadramawt), blocking the international road (likely with their vehicles), and against the local authorities' decision to ban fishing in the area's waters, which is their primary source of livelihood. An unidentified armed group aboard a vehicle threw a grenade on the protesters as they drove by, causing 7 injuries, some of which were severe. The demonstration was in response to Emirati forces preventing them from fishing. Previously, the Emirati forces stationed at Riyan provided fishermen with 800 Saudi Riyals monthly to stop fishing near the Riyan and Dhaba coasts, but these payments have ceased for several months.

The missiles hit the ship causing minor damage. There were no fatalities or injuries and the ship continued its route.

On 2 September 2024, at around 9:30 am Sanaa time, suspected Houthi forces launched 1 drone targeting the Amjad crude oil tanker (IMO: 9779800) in the South Red Sea around 58 nm west of Al Hudaydah. The Saudi company owning the ship denied that it was intentionally targeted by the Houthis. Houthi forces did not claim the attack.

On 26 August 2024, residents staged a protest in Aden - Hayy al Aydarus (Craiter) demanding access to drinking water. The protestors demanded access to clean drinking water, stating that their neighborhood had been without water for over a month. They explained that they had resorted to using donkeys to fetch water from distant locations. The demonstrators marched from Shaab al Aydarus to the headquarters of the General Water Corporation. This was one of two similar demonstrations that day.

source: 2 December News; Ansar Allah; Yemen News Agency (SABA) - Houthi; Yemen Window
notes: On 25 August 2024, an unidentified explosive device exploded inside a school in Al Qalis village (Bani Matar, Sanaa), injuring 30 students. Sources differed as to the origin of the device (Houthi or anti-Houthi) and type. Some sources claimed that it was a Houthi landmine hidden inside the school, which they claimed Houthi forces used as a landmine storage. Other sources claimed that the explosion happened during a Houthi training on explosives inside the school. Houthi-affiliated sources claimed that the explosion resulted from a war remnant belonging to anti-Houthi forces, brought to the school by a student who found it in a nearby area. The student tampered with the projectile inside the classroom, leading to its detonation.
On 25 August 2024, Houthi forces fired mortar shells at As Siyahi village (At Taiziyah, Taizz). Casualties unknown.

notes: On 24 August 2024, STC forces (coded as STC generic forces) clashed with Houthi forces on the Thirah front (Lawdar, Abyan). Houthi forces opened fire at the STC forces using medium and heavy weapons, and the STC forces responded via unspecified means and killed a number of Houthi fighters. Unclear fatalities coded as 3.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-)

Casualties unknown. Houthi forces did not publish a corresponding strike report.

source: Ansar Allah; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); Yemen News Agency (SABA) - Houthi; Yemen Window
notes: On 23 August 2024, a landmine leftover from previous unidentified military activity exploded in Qazabah village (Ad Durayhimi, Al Hudaydah) killing 1 civilian. Sources differed as to the origin of the landmine (Houthi or anti-Houthi).
On 23 August 2024, a suspected Houthi landmine exploded in Mahliyah district (coded to district center Al Amud) (Marib), injuring 1 civilian. There were no fatalities.

actor1: Police Forces of Yemen (2017-) Houthi - Prison Guards
source: Abductees Mothers Association; Al Masdar; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG
notes: Around 23 August 2024 (as reported), Houthi forces killed 1 prisoner, likely by torturing him, in a Houthi prison in Amran City. The reason for the attack was not reported. The prisoner was from Suwayr district and was abducted on his way to Sanaa on 1 June 2024 (coded as a separate event). The reason behind the attack was not reported.

On 23 August 2024, members from from Al Sanhan and Bani Hushish clans clashed in Dar Salam (Sanhan, Sanaa) using swords, clubs, and knives, and over a land dispute. During the clashes, an armed Al Sanhan tribesman shot and killed 1 Bani Hushaysh member and injured 1 another. He was later arrested.

actor1: Military Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council
source: 26 September News - Houthi; Al Masdar; Al Masirah; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); Twitter; Undisclosed Source; Yemeni Army - IRG
notes: Interception: On 23 August 2024, around 3:30 am, IRG forces claimed to have intercepted 3 Houthi Khatif-1 and Khatif-2 armed drones that were targeting Safir Oil Facility (Marib). The drones were launched from an area between Dahiadha and Qarn Al Sayari in Al Jawf governorate. Initial reports blamed the Houthi forces for the attack, although Houthi forces denied responsibility. An unknown entity calling itself the 'Free Tribesmen of Abidah' later claimed responsibility for the attack, claiming that it was an artillery attack in response to IRG forces encircling their region with barriers and checkpoints and seizing their lands. However, the veracity of the Abidah claim was unclear, as it was published and circulated by Houthi and pro-Houthi media. The attack could have been launched by a Houthi-affiliated faction acting on its own.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-)
notes: Interception: On 22 August 2024, at an unspecified time, US forces (whether warships or aircrafts unspecified) intercepted 1 Houthi drone over an unspecified Houthi controlled area in Yemen (coded to Al Hudaydah governorate based on previous activity). On the same day, USCENTCOM Claimed to have intercepted 2 Houthi UAVs in the Red Sea (coded as a separate event). CENTCOM claimed that it presented an imminent threat to shipping. Houthi forces did not publish a corresponding strike report.

actor1: Military Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council - Nation Shield Forces
notes: Movement of forces: On 22 August 2024, National Shield Forces assumed control of Al Wadiah border crossing (Zamakh wa Manwakh, Hadramawt) between Yemen and Saudi Arabia. According to sources, these forces took over key positions at the crossing, including the passport checkpoint, customs area, central gate, and the separating point between the two sides of the crossing. However, the military gate, external gate, and surrounding areas remain under the control of the 141st Brigade.

actor1: Police Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council - STC Aden Security
notes: On 22 August 2024, STC Aden Security forces reportedly kidnapped Sami Omar Bawazir, a former leader of the Southern Revolutionary Movement Council at the Aden - Caltex Roundabout (Al Mansura, Aden), taking him to an undisclosed location. Bawazir, who had previously been a leader within the Southern Revolutionary Movement Council, later joined the Southern Transitional Council and worked in the office of former Aden Security Director, Shalal Ali Shaya.

On 22 August 2024, Houthi forces abducted an unspecified number of civilians in the Khadir area (Dimnat Khadir, Taizz) for opposing the demolition and leveling of the walls and graves of a cemetery, taking them to an undisclosed location. The cemetery that was sold by Houthi leader, Baligh Al-Kahili, who is the director of the endowments of the Khadir district, to a merchant.

Other: On 22 August 2024, the Houthi government announced imposed financial charges on women seeking to travel without a male guardian, under the guise of 'regulating women's travel without a mahram' (coded to capital Sanaa) (Amanat al Asimah). Travelers have reported that the Houthis are charging fees for women to travel between areas under their control and regions governed by the IRG.

On 22 August 2024, tribal militants clashed with each other in erupted in the central market of Bayhan al Ulya (Bayhan, Shabwah) due to a long-standing dispute over the ownership of agricultural land between two local tribes. The Al Fatimah tribe was one of the two sides. The clashes resulted in injuries to the brother of the Bayhan district director and a prominent figures in the area, both from the Al Fatimah tribe.

Around 22 August 2024 (week of), Eritrean forces kidnapped 31 Yemeni fishermen in the South Red Sea. Houthi sources claimed the fishermen were kidnapped and transferred to an unspecified prison in Eritrean for 3 days where they were tortured and set free with one boat of their boats, while the other 2 boats were seized. The fishermen returned to the Al Hudaydah fishing port on 22 August 2024. Eritrean forces did not claim or make a statement regarding the incident.

On 22 August 2024, between 12:00 am and 1:00 am Sanaa time, Houthi forces launched 2 drones/missiles (coded as missiles based on other activity in the Red Sea) targeting the SW North Wind I bulk carrier (IMO: 9514004) in the Gulf of Aden. The Houthis claimed the company owning the ship was in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. The ship reported 2 explosions in close proximity to the ship. There were no fatalities or injuries, and the ship continued its route. The ship was targeted several times between 21 and 22 August (coded as separate events).
On 22 August 2024, Eritrean naval forces killed a Yemeni fisherman from Al Mukha while he was fishing in Yemeni territorial waters in the South Red Sea.

On 22 August 2024, around 8:00 pm Sanaa time, Houthi forces launched 1 drone boat targeting the SW North Wind I bulk carrier (IMO: 9514004) in the South Red Sea around 55 nm west of Hudaydah. The Houthis claimed the company owning the ship was in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. The ship reported 1 explosion in close proximity to the ship that caused minor damages. There were no fatalities or injuries, and the ship continued its route. The ship was targeted several times between 21 and 22 August (coded as separate events).

notes: Interception: On 22 August 2024, at an unspecified time, US forces (whether warships or aircrafts unspecified) intercepted 2 Houthi drones over the South Red Sea. Potential targets were unidentified/not reported. Houthi forces did not claim the attack.

On 21 August 2024, students of Razi University, through the University Student Forum, organized a Houthi-sponsored solidarity march in Sanaa (coded to Sanaa - At Talahum) (Maain, Amanat al Asimah) in solidarity with the Palestinian people and to denounce the 'Zionist genocide' in the context of the latest round of violence in Israel-Palestine. The march began at the university's main building and proceeded through several streets in Sanaa.

notes: On 21 August 2024, students and staff at Sana'a University held a massive Houthi sponsored march in Sanaa - Sanaa University (Maain, Amanat al Asimah) in solidarity with the Palestinian people and with Houthi actions in support of Palestine, and to denounce the 'Zionist crimes' in the context of the latest round of violence in Israel-Palestine. The participants, including the university president, deans, and various affiliates, raised Yemeni and Palestinian flags, denouncing the international and Arab 'silence' regarding the high number of Palestinian casualties.

actor1: Police Forces of Yemen (2017-) Houthi - Security and Intelligence Service
notes: On 21 August 2024, Houthi Security and Intelligence Service forces abducted 1 journalist from an unspecified location in Amran governorate (coded to governorate capital Amran), taking him to an undisclosed location. The reason behind the abduction was not reported. The same journalist was initially detained in June 2023 for documenting a Houthi raid on a wedding and was released after 35 days.

On 21 August 2024, 2 Houthi supervisors (mushrif) assaulted an elderly woman in Al Makhadir District (coded to district center Al Makhadir) (Ibb) and also assaulted her home and agricultural land in an unspecified way. The woman later published a video in which she burnt her headscarf in protest of the supervisor's actions. The source claimed that Houthis have assaulted women in their private properties in the past.

On 21 August 2024, dozens of demonstrators blocked roads by setting fire to car tires in the streets of Al Mukalla (Al Mukalla City, Hadramawt) to denounce increased power outages in the city, which have worsened over past days.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-)
source: Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; USCENTCOM; Yemen News Agency (SABA) - Houthi
notes: On 21 August 2024, at an unspecified time, US forces conducted raids/strikes to destroy a Houthi surface-to-air missile and radar system in As Salif coastal district (coded to As Salif Port) (Al Hudaydah). CENTCOM claimed the destruction of Houthi surface-to-air missile and radar system that day without providing locations while Houthi sources reported 3 raids on As Salif. IRG media claimed that underneath the As Salif port, Houthi forces have been storing weapons and sheltering Iranian military experts that direct Houthi naval operations in the Red Sea, claiming that a number of experts and solders were killed from the airstrikes. However, no independent source verified these claims. Casualties unknown.

Interception: On 21 August 2024, at an unspecified time, the French frigate Chevalier Paul intercepted 1 Houthi drone boat in the South Red Sea, likely targeting the Sounion crude oil tanker. The destroyer was answering a distress call by the 29 crew members of the Sounion after they were forced to abandon ship due to an earlier Houthi attack (coded as a separate event).

On 21 August 2024, At around 6:15 am Sanaa time, Houthi forces exchanged fire via small arms with security forces onboard the Sounion crude oil tanker (IMO: 9312145) in the South Red Sea around 78 nm west of Al Hudaydah. There were no fatalities or injuries. The Houthi forces approached the ship on 2 skiffs, one carrying up to 5 gunmen and the other 12 gunmen. The fire exchange started after the ship's security forces fired warning shots at the skiffs for approaching within 2 km of the ship. The Houthis claimed the company owning the ship was in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. The ship was targeted again later on that day (coded as separate events).

source: Al Masdar; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; EUNAVFOR - Aspides; UKMTO; Yemeni Army - Houthi
notes: On 21 August 2024, between 7am and 9am Sanaa time, Houthi forces fired 3 drones and missiles targeting the Sounion crude oil tanker (IMO: 9312145) in the South Red Sea around 84 nm northwest of Al Hudaydah, The Houthis claimed the company owning the ship was in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. All projectiles hit the ship, damaging the engine compartment and starting a fire, and slightly injuring a crew member. The ship was abandoned and left anchored in the area. By the following day, UKMTO reported that three different fires were observed on the ship and that it began drifting. The ship was targeted several other times that day (coded as separate events).

Recruitment: Around 16 August 2024 (as reported), the Hadramawt Tribal Alliance launched a recruitment campaign to enlist tribal militants in preparation for potential military confrontations in the Hadramawt plateau (coded to Hadramawt governorate capital Al Mukalla). The alliance established tribal military sites in the region, reinforcing them with armed tribesmen from various local tribes. This recruitment effort was part of a broader escalation plan aimed at taking control of land and resources in Hadramawt. The campaign followed an ultimatum issued to the government on 9 August 2024, in which the alliance demanded fair representation in governance and a fair share of the region's wealth, threatening armed action if these demands were not met.

actor2: Military Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council
source: Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Twitter; Yemen Window
notes: On 16 August 2024, unknown tribal gunmen opened fire at IRG soldiers from the 2nd Road Protection Brigade in Wadi Marib district (coded to Al Husun) (Marib), killing 2 soldiers and 1 civilian driver. The attack occurred as the soldiers were constructing defensive barricades near the district despite prior warnings from local tribes against such activities. 3 fatalities.

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council - STC Shabwani Defense Forces
assoc_actor_2: Al Abu Bakr Bin Farid Tribal Group (Yemen); Al Ahmad Bin Farid Tribal Group (Yemen)
source: Al Amaliqah; Dera Al Ganoob; Twitter
notes: On 16 August 2024, forces from the Giants Brigades and STC Shabwani Defense Forces abducted members of the Al Abu Bakr Bin Farid and Al Ahmad Bin Farid tribes in As Said district (coded to district center Al Said) (Shabwah) as part of the intervention to stop the ongoing clashes between the two tribes. Militants from the two tribes had been clashing with each other following an incident where Al Ahmad Bin Farid gunmen ambushed a tribal leader from Abu Bakr bin Farid with an RPG, killing 1 of his escorts and injuring 2 others due to tribal revenge on 7 August 2024 (coded as a separate event).

actor1: AQAP: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
actor2: Military Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council - STC Support and Reinforcement Brigades
source: Al Masdar; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; An Nusra Media; Twitter; Yemeni Army - IRG
notes: On 16 August 2024, an AQAP suicide car bomber driving a bomb-laden vehicle (VBIED) rammed the barracks of the 3rd Brigade of the STC Support and Reinforcement Brigades in Al Furayd area near the Umm Surrah Junction (Mudiyah, Abyan), killing 16 (19 according to some sources) STC soldiers and injuring dozens. AQAP media claimed that the attack left 50 total casualties. At least 17 fatalities, including the suicide bomber, were coded.

On 15 August 2024, dozens of Amhara and Oromo migrants brawled with sticks near Ash Sharq Al Awsat restaurant in Aden - Al Basatin (Dar Sad, Aden). The reason behind the incident was not reported, but it is likely related to deadly clashes between Ethiopian migrants in the city in 2023. Casualties unknown.

On 15 August 2024, residents held a large protest stand in July 13 school in Al Jabziyah (Al Maafer, Taizz) in solidarity with journalist Mohammed Al Qadhi, who had been arrested since 2 months for his 'nationalist' views.

On 13 August 2024, the Inclusive Hadramawt Conference held a large protest stand in Al Mukalla City (Hadramawt) against the deteriorating living conditions and services in the city.

On 13 August 2024, protesters from Ash Shihr district gathered at the Ad Dabbah checkpoint near Ad Dabbah Port (Ash Shihr, Hadramawt) after IRG forces at the checkpoint prevented them from crossing to participate in a large protest in Al Mukalla City. The protesters denounced the blockage and called on the Hadhramaut Tribal Alliance to intervene. The protesters also demanded the dismissal of Hadhramaut's governor.

notes: Around 13 August 2024 (as reported), Houthi forces killed 1 prisoner by torturing him in the central security prison in Sanaa - Central Security Camp (As Sabain, Amanat al Asimah). The reason for the attack was not reported. The prisoner was from Ibb and was arrested 10 years ago.

actor1: Police Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council - STC Aden Security
source: Al Masdar; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Mareb Press; Twitter
notes: On 13 August 2024, STC security forces (coded as STC Aden Security) abducted 1 activist from the al Fursan Hotel on 90 Street in Aden - Al Mansurah (Al Mansura, Aden) for organizing protests demanding the disclosure of the fate of Ali Ashal Al Jaadani, a colonel from Abyan governorate that was abducted at the hands of suspected STC Security Belt forces on 12 June. STC forces claimed to have arrested him on the charges of assaulting a senior legal official, denying that his arrest was related to the case of Al-Jaadani or that he was involved in organizing protests regarding that case. The activist was released on 28 September 2024.

On 13 August 2024, Saudi forces (coded under ORH) opened fire on Al Thabit town in the border district of Qatabir (Sadah) in Yemen, injuring 2 African migrants. The attack weapon was unspecified. There were no fatalities.
On 13 August 2024, Saudi forces (coded under ORH) carried out a drone attack against Al Ghawr area in Ghamr border district (Sadah) in Yemen. Casualties unknown.

On 13 August 2024, around 6:15 am Sanaa time, suspected Houthi forces fired at least 1 drone/missile (coded as missile based on other activity in the Red Sea) targeting the Delta Atlantica crude oil tank (IMO: 9419101) in the South Red Sea around 89 nm west-northwest of Al Hudaydah. There were no fatalities or injuries as the drone/missile exploded in close proximity to the ship. The ship was targeted several other times that day (coded as separate events). Houthi forces did not claim the attack.

On 13 August 2024, around 4:00 am Sanaa time, suspected Houthi forces fired at least 1 drone/missile (coded as missile based on other activity in the Red Sea) targeting the On Phoenix crude oil tanker (IMO: 9893228) in the South Red Sea around 97 nm northwest of Al Hudaydah. There were no fatalities or injuries as the drone/missile exploded around 180-185 m from the ship. The vessel was not hit or damaged, and continued its voyage normally. Houthi forces did not claim the attack.

Interception: On 13 August 2024, around 7:05 am Sanaa time, suspected Houthi forces launched 1 drone boat targeting the Delta Atlantica crude oil tank (IMO: 9419101) in the South Red Sea around 99 nm northwest of Al Hudaydah. The armed security team aboard the Delta Atlantica disabled the drone boat with small arms fire after the drone boat collided with the ship and failed to detonate. The ship was targeted several other times that day (coded as separate events). Houthi forces did not claim the attack.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-)
notes: On 13 August 2024, at an unspecified time, US forces (whether warships or aircrafts unspecified but coded as airstrike based on previous activity) conducted strikes to destroy 2 Houthi boats (type of boats unidentified) in the South Red Sea. Pro-IRG sources claimed that the boats had Houthi soldiers on them and they were all killed in the strikes. On 22 August, the body of 1 Houthi soldier was found on the shore of Al Hudaydah. Casualties coded as at least 1.

On 13 August 2024, around 1:45 am Sanaa time, suspected Houthi forces detonated 2 sea mines targeting the Delta Atlantica crude oil tank (IMO: 9419101) in the South Red Sea around 63 nm west-southwest of Al Hudaydah. There were no fatalities or injuries as the seamines exploded around 555 m from the ship. UKMTO reported two unidentified explosions near the ship while another source claimed that the explosions were the result of sea mines prematurely detonating while they had been laid out on the ship's route. The explosions followed a suspicious approach and flashing lights toward the ship by a skiff. The ship was targeted several other times that day (coded as separate events). Houthi forces did not claim the attack.

source: Aden al Ghad; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); Yemen Window
notes: On 12 August 2024, a suspected Houthi landmine exploded in Hays City (Al Hudaydah), injuring 2 civilians. There were no fatalities.

source: Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Khabar News Agency (Yemen)

There were no fatalities.

Most of the looted farms belonged to farmers from Hammat Sarar village, where Houthi forces had been involved in deadly clashes with Al Qayfa tribal militants since 7 August 2024.

actor2: Al Ahmad Bin Farid Tribal Militia (Yemen)
notes: On 9 August 2024, militants from Al Abu Bakr Bin Farid and Al Ahmad Bin Farid tribes clashed using various weapons in As Said district (coded to district center Al Said) (Shabwah) for the second consecutive day. Casualties unknown. These clashes followed an incident where Al Ahmad Bin Farid gunmen ambushed a tribal leader from Abu Bakr bin Farid with an RPG, killing 1 of his escorts and injuring 2 others due to tribal revenge on 7 August 2024 (coded as a separate incident).

On 9 August 2024, Al Maidh and Al Maraziq tribal militants clashed near Al Jalfuz checkpoint (Ataq, Shabwah) over a land dispute. Maraziq tribesmen claimed ownership of the land and started construction on it, which led to the clashes. There were no fatalities or injuries.

source: Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Twitter

notes: On 9 August 2024, Houthi forces raided a house in Dar ash Sharaf (Al Mashannah, Ibb), firing randomly before storming in and assaulting and stabbing 1 resident, injuring him. One source also claimed he was shot in the foot. There were no fatalities. The incident was part of a series of ongoing Houthi raids in the area, allegedly in response to attacks against Houthi forces. The victim was accused of throwing a grenade at a police station and firing at it in retaliation for the death of his friend who had been killed weeks earlier while detained in a Houthi prison.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-)
source: Ansar Allah; USCENTCOM; Yemen News Agency (SABA) - Houthi
notes: Interception: On 9 August 2024, at an unspecified time, US forces conducted raids/strikes to intercept 1 Houthi drone boat in Ras Isa (As Salif, Al Hudaydah). notes: On 20 July 2024, Israeli fighter jets conducted 3 strikes on Al Hudaydah - Port (Al Hali) that damaged two cranes, a marine control tower, and at least 33 fuel tanks, causing large fires with fuel burning for days after the strikes. An aid vessel also sustained minor damage to its fuel storage facility and to a crane onboard. The strikes killed at least 9 Yemen Petroleum Company port employees, and injured at least 80 others including many that were hospitalized with severe burns. Some sources claimed a total of 14 fatalities but the number was unverified. The strikes were part of Israeli Operation Outstretched Arm that struck Al Hudaydah - Port and the Ras al Kathib power station near Dayr al Afif as a response to a Houthi drone strike that killed 1 person in Tel Aviv on 19 July. They were the first Israeli strikes on Yemen.

There were no fatalities or injuries although the drone caused minor damage to containers on deck and started a small fire after it exploded 5-10 m from the ship. One of the other weapons (unclear which one) also caused a hole in the stern of the ship. The drone boat exploded 30 m from the ship following defensive fire from the armed security team onboard, while the missiles exploded at distances of 5 m, 30-50 m, and 100 m from the ship. Houthi forces claimed a joint drone and ballistic missile attack targeting the Pumba. The US affiliation of the ship was not verified.

notes: On 19 July 2024, Houthi forces exchanged fire with a resident in Al Manjarah (Suwayr, Amran) as they stormed a mosque during Friday prayers and attempted to detain the resident, presenting him as a 'wanted' person. The clash led to killing a total of 6 people including the resident, 4 Houthi fighters, and 1 civilian woman. 3 other women were injured. One of the sources noted that the Abu Said tribes flocked to the area and force Houthi forces to leave the village.

Movement of forces: On 19 July 2024, Houthi forces sent 30 armed vehicles and around 300 members to siege Al Manjarah (Suwayr, Amran) after the killing of 4 Houthi members earlier that day in the area by a 'wanted' civilian (coded as a separate event).

On 15 July 2024, at around 8:30 am Sanaa time, Houthi forces on two small crafts exchanged fire with the armed security team of the Bentley I oil products tanker (IMO: 9253129) in the South Red Sea around 70 nm southwest of Al Hudaydah. There were no fatalities or injuries. Houthi forces also attempted to strike the Bentley I with a drone boat during the attack. The drone boat collided with the ship twice but failed to detonate, leading Houthi forces to abort the attack after 15 minutes. Houthi forces fired missiles at the ship later in the day following this initial attack (coded as a separate event) and claimed a drone, ballistic missile, and drone boat attack targeting the ship claiming affiliation with companies in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. The Bentley I was owned by an Israel-registered company and carrying vegetable oil from Russia to China.

On 15 July 2024, between 12:00 pm and 6:30 pm Sanaa time, Houthi forces fired 4 anti-ship ballistic missiles targeting the Bentley I oil products tanker (IMO: 9253129) in the South Red Sea around 70 nm southwest of Al Hudaydah claiming affiliation with companies in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missiles impacted the water in close proximity to the ship with the closest ones landing around 10-15 m from the ship. Houthi forces had attacked the ship earlier in the day exchanging fire with the armed security team on board the ship. The Bentley I was owned by an Israel-registered company and carrying vegetable oil from Russia to China.

On 15 July 2024, at around 3:00 pm Sanaa time, Houthi forces launched 1 drone boat targeting the Chios Lion crude oil tanker (IMO: 9398280) in the South Red Sea around 97 nm northwest of Al Hudaydah claiming affiliation with companies in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. There were no fatalities or injuries although the drone boat struck the ship on its port side causing minor damage. The Chios Lion was sailing southbound when it was struck and turned around to sail north out of the threat area following the attack.

notes: On 13 July 2024, IRG forces and the Popular Resistance clashed with Houthi forces and 'thwarted their infiltration attempt' in Tibbat Yasin in the Hadhran area northwest of Taizz (At Taiziyah, Taizz) killing 2 Houthi fighters and injuring 4 others.

On 13 July 2024, employees of the Ministry of Fisheries held a Houthi-sponsored demonstration in front of the ministry building in Sanaa - Assafiyah (Assafiyah, Amanat al Asimah) in celebration of the Houthi dismantling of 'the American-Zionist spy network' and in solidarity with the Palestinian people and with Houthi actions in support of Palestine in the context of the latest round of violence in Israel-Palestine. Houthi authorities claimed on 10 June that they had arrested members of a 'CIA-linked US-Israeli spy network' that had been operating in Yemen since before 2015. Houthi-affiliated political officials took part in the demonstration.

assoc_actor_1: Government of Yemen (2017-) Houthi; Labor Group (Yemen)
source: Ansar Allah; Yemen News Agency (SABA) - Houthi
notes: On 13 July 2024, employees of the Yemen Petroleum Company and the National Cement Company held a Houthi-sponsored demonstration in Sanaa city (Amanat al Asimah) in celebration of the Houthi dismantling of 'the American-Zionist spy network' and in solidarity with the Palestinian people and with Houthi actions in support of Palestine in the context of the latest round of violence in Israel-Palestine. A separate demonstration was held by the Cleaning sector and the General Union of Municipal Workers. Houthi authorities claimed on 10 June that they had arrested members of a 'CIA-linked US-Israeli spy network' that had been operating in Yemen since before 2015.

actor2: Military Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council
notes: On 13 July 2024, Houthi drones and artillery struck IRG forces on Al Aqrud front southwest of Taizz (Al Misrakh, Taizz). Casualties unknown.

Detonation: On 13 July 2024, a hand grenade detonated on a motorcycle on the road between Al Khawkhah district in Al Hudaydah to Al Waziiyah Junction area (coded to Al Waziiyah Junction) (Mawza, Taizz), killing 1 man and injuring 1 other. The victims were travelling on the motorcycle with the grenade, which detonated on the road due to a traffic accident. 1 fatality.
On 13 July 2024, a suspected Saudi-led coalition unexploded ordnance exploded in Bani Siyah (Razih, Sadah) killing 1 civilian.

source: 2 December News; Al Masdar; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Al Sahil Al Gharbi
notes: On 13 July 2024, tribal militants from the Bayt Al Marghami family clashed with Houthi forces led by a senior Houthi militant from the Bayt Al Jaafari family in Uzlat Bani Margham (Al Qafr, Ibb) after a funeral over old tribal disputes. 1 civilian bystander was killed during the clashes.

On 13 July 2024, at around 8:30 am Sanaa time, suspected Houthi forces fired 2 missiles at a commercial ship (name undisclosed) in the South Red Sea. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missiles impacted the water. Houthi forces did not claim the attack.

The Chrysalis had passed through the Suez Canal from the Mediterranean Sea on 7 July heading to India.

notes: Interception: On 11 July 2024, at an unspecified time, US forces conducted 5 strikes/raids to intercept 1 Houthi drone in Ras Isa (As Salif, Al Hudaydah). CENTCOM claimed that it presented an imminent threat to shipping. CENTCOM claimed the destruction of 1 Houthi drone that day without providing locations while Houthi sources reported 5 raids on Ras Isa.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-)
notes: Interception: On 11 July 2024, at an unspecified time, US forces (whether warships or aircrafts unspecified) intercepted 5 Houthi drone boats in the South Red Sea. Potential targets were unidentified/not reported. Houthi forces did not claim the attack.

On 11 July 2024, at around 11:00 pm Sanaa time, suspected Houthi forces fired 5 missiles targeting the Rostrum Stoic bulk carrier (IMO: 9955911) in the Strait of Bab el Mandeb around 15 nm southwest of Al Mukha. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missiles all impacted the water in close proximity of the ship with the closest landing around 200 m from the ship. Houthi forces did not claim the attack, likely because the ship was carrying Russian cargo and was targeted by mistake. The Rostrum Stoic was carrying Russian cargo bound for India.
