Around 9 July 2024 (as reported), Houthi forces claimed a drone attack targeting the MSC Patnaree III container ship (IMO: 9240328) in the Gulf of Aden claiming Israeli affiliation of the ship. There were no fatalities or injuries as the drone likely impacted the water before reaching the intended target. The attack was not confirmed by other sources. Houthi forces have been labeling MSC ships as 'Israeli' possibly because of the dual Swiss-Israeli citizenship of one of MSC's co-founder and co-owner. The MSC Patnaree III was recorded as leaving the port of Berbera in Somalia in the Gulf of Aden on 5 July, where it had arrived on 2 July.

Around 9 July 2024 (as reported), Houthi forces claimed a drone attack targeting the Marathopolis container ship (IMO: 9477804) in the Arabian Sea (coded to West Arabian Sea) claiming affiliation with companies in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. There were no fatalities or injuries as the drone likely impacted the water before reaching the intended target. The attack was not confirmed by other sources. The Marathopolis had left Mombasa in Kenya on 4 July and arrived at Salalah in Oman on 9 July passing through the Indian Ocean and the Arabian Sea.

source: EUNAVFOR - Aspides; Tradewinds; UKMTO; Yemeni Army - Houthi
notes: On 9 July 2024, at around 7:30 am Sanaa time, Houthi forces fired 5 ballistic/cruise missiles targeting the Maersk Sentosa container ship (IMO: 9315202) in the Arabian Sea (coded to West Arabian Sea) around 180 nm east of Nishtun claiming US affiliation of the ship. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missiles impacted the water including one in close proximity to the ship around 0.5 nm. The ship was US-flagged, and owned, operated, and managed by US-based companies. Houthi forces claimed to have targeted the ship with ballistic and cruise missiles while at least 1 explosion was reported near the ship.

Casualties unknown. The tribes managed to capture 2 Giants fighters and the brigades replied with artillery shelling.

On 2 July 2024, unidentified gunmen attacked 1 civilian in Khanfir district (coded to Jaar) (Abyan). The source noted that the gunmen attempted to abduct the civilian while he was driving home from work but the civilian resisted leading the gunmen to burn his car. The civilian was the manager of the Hassan Dam project. The reason behind the attack was not reported. The source noted that the Finance Officer of the same project was abducted with his guard the month prior and was released through tribal mediation (coded as a separate event).

notes: On 2 July 2024, Al Ahmad and Al Abu Bakr tribesmen from Al Farid tribe, a sub-tribe of Awaliq tribe, clashed in As Said district (coded to Al Said) (Shabwah). The clash resulted in 4 fatalities over 30 June - 2 July. Fatalities split between 3 days. The clash started following the killing of 1 tribesman as part of a long-standing tribal feud (unclear when the killing took place). It started on June 30 and stopped temporarily on July 1 following tribal mediation before resuming on 2 July.

On 2 July 2024, Houthi forces shelled with mortar bombs villages in Al Jafrah (Al Abdiyah, Marib) causing material damage. There were no fatalities or injuries. This followed clashes in the area the previous day.

On 2 July 2024, Al Jaadani tribesmen gathered in Zinjibar security headquarters (Zingibar, Abyan) demanding the STC Security Belt forces to release Ali Ashal Al Jaadani, a colonel from Abyan governorate that was abducted at the hands of suspected STC Security Belt forces on 12 June. One source claimed that the tribes also set up roadblocks only letting by trucks that carried damage-prone goods. The protesters said they would escalate by heading to Aden if the tribesman was not released.

source: Al Masirah; Yemen News Agency (SABA) - Houthi
notes: On 2 July 2024, employees of the Water, Electricity, and Real Estate Project Authority held 3 Houthi-sponsored demonstrations in Dhamar City (Dhamar) in solidarity with the Palestinian people and 'Resistance' and denouncing the 'Zionist crimes' in Gaza in the context of the latest round of violence in Israel-Palestine. Houthi-affiliated political officials took part in the demonstration.

Movement of forces: On 2 July 2024, Houthi forces composed of 15 military vehicles deployed to locations in Al Jawf governorate (coded to Al Hazm). The source noted that the deployment followed the 'mysterious killing' of commanders in the area.

On 2 July 2024, Houthi forces abducted Ahmad al-Nunu the undersecretary in the Houthi Ministry of Education from his house in central Sanaa city (Amanat al Asimah). The reason behind the abduction was not reported.

source: Aden al Ghad; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG
notes: On 2 July 2024, unidentified gunmen shot and injured 1 Houthi leader (likely off-duty) in front of his house in Sanaa city (Amanat al Asimah). The source claimed that the attack was due to the leader's rejection to deploy to the Marib front. The leader died of his injuries the next day at the Military Hospital in Sanaa.
On 2 July 2024, Saudi forces (coded under ORH) carried out a drone attack against Jalha area in Monabbih border district (Sadah) in Yemen damaging 1 civilian vehicle. Casualties unknown.

On 2 July 2024, Houthi forces claimed a cruise missile attack targeting a 'vital target' in Haifa in a joint operation with the Islamic Resistance in Iraq (coded to North Red Sea). There were no fatalities or injuries as the missiles likely impacted the water in the Red Sea before reaching the intended target. The attack was not confirmed by other sources.
On 1 July 2024, Al Laqmush armed tribesmen clashed in Hada (Habban, Shabwah). Casualties unknown. The reason behind the clash was not reported.

actor1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-)
notes: On 1 July 2024, at an unspecified time, US forces conducted strikes to destroy 1 Houthi radar site in an unspecified Houthi-controlled area inside Yemen (coded to Al Hudaydah governorate based on previous activity). Casualties unknown. Houthi forces did not publish a corresponding strike report.

On 1 July 2024, Houthi forces clashed with Al Ghanam tribesmen after shelling civilian homes in Al Ghanim (Al Abdiyah, Marib) as they were looking for 1 wanted individual who killed a Houthi military official. Casualties unknown.

actor1: Police Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council
notes: On 1 July 2024, Ash Shamayatayn IRG police forces shot and killed 1 civilian in his house in Dar Sharaf in At Turbah city (Ash Shamayatayn, Taizz) following a physical altercation. The source claimed that the fight started after the policemen fired live rounds when they entered the house to scare the residents.
On 1 July 2024, a communal militia clashed with Houthi-affiliated militiamen in Waraqah village (Sanhan, Sanaa) over a land dispute. The clash resulted in 2 fatalities and 3 injuries.

source: 2 December News; Al Sahil Al Gharbi; Yemen Window
notes: On 1 July 2024, armed clashes erupted between Hamdan and Ash Shawlan tribes using different types of weapons in Hisn ad Daymah (Al Hazm, Al Jawf). Casualties unknown. The reason behind the clashes was not reported. Clashes took place across 30 June - 4 July.

source: Aden al Ghad; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Mareb Press
notes: On 1 July 2024, Al Ahmad and Al Abu Bakr tribesmen from Al Farid tribe, a sub-tribe of Awaliq tribe, clashed in As Said district (coded to Al Said) (Shabwah). The clash resulted in 4 fatalities over 30 June - 2 July. Fatalities split between 3 days. The clash started following the killing of 1 tribesman as part of a long-standing tribal feud (unclear when the killing took place). It started on June 30 and stopped temporarily on July 1 following tribal mediation before resuming on 2 July.

source: Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Mareb Press; Yemeni Army - IRG
notes: On 1 July 2024, Giants Brigades forces and the 2nd Brigade of the Giants-affiliated Saba Axis clashed with Houthi forces that launched an offensive in Adh Dhira and in Jabal Arash in Al Jafrah (Al Abdiyah, Marib). Sources reported dozens of Houthi fatalities including 1 Houthi commander and several Giants and Saba Axis fatalities. Unclear fatalities coded as 12 and split between 2 locations. One source claimed that the Houthi forces advanced 8 kilometers before being pushed back. Another source noted that the Houthi attack included drones and artillery.

source: Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Mareb Press; Yemeni Army - IRG
notes: On 1 July 2024, Giants Brigades forces and the 2nd Brigade of the Giants-affiliated Saba Axis clashed with Houthi forces that launched an offensive in Adh Dhira and in Jabal Arash in Al Jafrah (Al Abdiyah, Marib). Sources reported dozens of Houthi fatalities including 1 Houthi commander and several Giants and Saba Axis fatalities. Unclear fatalities coded as 12 and split between 2 locations. One source claimed that the Houthi forces advanced 8 kilometers before being pushed back. Another source noted that the Houthi attack included drones and artillery.

source: Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Khabar News Agency (Yemen); Yemen Window
notes: On 1 July 2024, four suspected Houthi fighters attacked 1 female lawyer in Sanaa city (Amanat al Asimah). The source claimed that the reason behind the attack was that the lawyer had filed a case against the group. The lawyer was taken to a hospital in Sanaa for medical attention following the attack.

actor2: Military Forces of Yemen (2022-) Presidential Leadership Council
source: 26 September News - IRG; Al Mashhad Al Yemeni - Pro-IRG; Yemeni Army - IRG
notes: On 1 July 2024, IRG forces and the Popular Resistance clashed with Houthi forces and 'thwarted their infiltration attempt' in Taizz - Street 40 front (Al Qahirah, Taizz) causing 'Houthi material and human losses.' Unclear fatalities coded as 3.

Around 1 July 2024 (as reported), Houthi forces claimed a cruise missile attack targeting the Lucky Sailor chemical/oil products tanker (IMO: 9464352) in the Mediterranean Sea (coded to North Red Sea) claiming affiliation with companies in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missiles likely impacted the water in the Red Sea before reaching the intended target. The attack was not confirmed by other sources. The Lucky Sailor had been anchored in the Mediterranean Sea off Port Said, Egypt, since 28 June.

Around 1 July 2024 (as reported), Houthi forces claimed a cruise and ballistic missile attack targeting the Delonix chemical/oil products tanker (IMO: 9298387) in the South Red Sea claiming US affiliation of the ship. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missiles likely impacted the water before reaching the intended target. The attack was not confirmed by other sources. The US affiliation of the ship was not verified. The Delonix crossed the Suez Canal southbound on 24 June and was targeted a first time by Houthi forces on 28 June around 150 nm northwest of Al Hudaydah.

Around 1 July 2024 (as reported), Houthi forces claimed 1 cruise missile attack targeting the MSC Unific VI container ship (IMO: 9168843) in the Arabian Sea (coded to West Arabian Sea) claiming Israeli affiliation of the ship. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missiles likely impacted the water before reaching the intended target. The attack was not confirmed by other sources. Houthi forces have been labeling MSC ships as 'Israeli' possibly because of the dual Swiss-Israeli citizenship of one of MSC's co-founder and co-owner. The Unific VI left Colombo in Sri Lanka on 23 June for Djibouti where it arrived on 2 July after sailing through the Arabian Sea and the Gulf of Aden.

Around 1 July 2024 (as reported), Houthi forces claimed a cruise missile attack targeting the Anvil Point ro-ro cargo ship (IMO: 9248540) in the Indian Ocean claiming UK affiliation of the ship. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missiles likely impacted the water before reaching the intended target. The attack was not confirmed by other sources with the operators of the ship refuting the claim. The Anvil Point was UK-flagged, owned, operated, and managed by UK-based companies, and worked as an auxiliary military sealift ship for the UK Royal Navy. The Anvil Point left Duqm in Oman on 28 for Mombasa in Kenya where it arrived on 4 July after sailing through the Indian Ocean.
